lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _These_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/app.These.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run app.These.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

* The main entry point of the Duke application (Renamed to 'These').
* The These class coordinates interactions between the user interface,
* task list, storage, and parser. It is responsible for initializing the system,
* running the main command loop, and persisting changes to storage.
* The constructor creates a new {@link Ui}, {@link Storage}
* and {@link TaskList} instance. It tries to load in existing tasks from the storage
* and displays an error and continues with an empty task list
* Return the task list used by this These instance
* Return the Ui used by this These instance
* Return the storage used by this These instance
* @return {@link Storage} instance responsible for updating and loading tasks
* Runs the main loop of the These application
* Begins with intro message, and sets isExit boolean to false. While each command
* returns true, isExit will remain false until we receive an {@link ExitCommand}
* which returns false, in that case isExit will be true, and we exit the loop.
* Represents a command that clears all tasks from the task list.
* Create new ClearCommand associated with a These instance
* Removes all tasks from TaskList associated with the These instance,
* updates Storage with the cleared TaskList, and shows message upon completion
* @return true if command is executed successfully
public boolean run(String input) throws TheseException {

* Represents a command that terminates the application
* When executed, display the outro message through the {@link Ui} component and signals
* the main loop in {@link These} to stop running.
* Create a new ExitCommand associated with a These instance
* @param these the main application instance that provides access
* to the task list, UI, and storage
* On execution, display the outro message and return false, causing the loop in these
* to break and exiting the program.
* @return false, allowing user to exit the program
* @throws TheseException not thrown in this method, but declared to
* align with the implementation in the {@link Command} interface

* Represents a Command that marks a specified task in the task list as done
* When executed, the {@code MarkCommand} parses user input to obtain the
* index of the task, then changes the {@link Task}s marked status from
* false to true. If there is no index given, MarkCommand throws a {@link TheseException}.
* If the task is already marked, the command
* still succeeds and returns the confirmation message.
* Constructs a new MarkCommand associated with a given {@link These} instance.

* and marking that task as done. A success message is then displayed.

* @throws TheseException if the task number is missing
